title: LIVE: AFR Energy Summit: The rules keep changing says Origin Energy
text:
Simon Evans

A large ''community'' storage battery operated by an electricity distribution company which households can choose to have a ''virtual'' slice of is a much better bet in keeping power costs down for consumers in the future, than for each household to buy their own storage battery, an Ausgrid executive says.

Ausgrid chief customer officer Rob Amphlett Lewis told the Australian Financial Review National Energy Summit that a community battery would ultimately be more cost effective.

"Everyone buying their own battery is a bit like everyone buying their own holiday home,'' he said.

Ausgrid said there was huge potential in giving households the opportunity to have a ''virtual partition'' in the bigger community battery where they could choose how to benefit best for their household needs.

Households had no extra tolerance for higher prices, and the community battery was one way of keeping prices down.

"It's simple, sharing is better,'' he said.

Mr Amphlett Lewis said a community storage battery could be ''co-located'' with existing infrastructure operated by Ausgrid.

Ausgrid has 1.5 million household customers in NSW and 200,000 business customers.

He said the community battery concept had wider applications."We think this is a solution that can be rolled out across the community,'' he said.
description: A ten year energy and climate policy vacuum, and the threat of short-term market rule changes, has left energy suppliers unable to invest in power urgently needed by the market: Origin Energy chief executive.
